sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in an application (no. 38647/09) against Hungary lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Hungarian national, Mr Gábor Ónodi (“the applicant”), on 16 July 2009.
2.  The applicant was represented by Ms M. Regász, a lawyer practising in Budapest. The Hungarian Government (“the Government”) were represented by Mr Z. Tallódi, Agent, Ministry of Justice.
3.  The applicant alleged, in particular, that the Hungarian authorities had failed to take effective steps to enforce his right to contact with his daughter, in breach of Article 8 of the Convention.
4.  On 14 March 2016 this complaint was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
sections.circumstances:
5.  The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Szajol.
6.  On 6 October 1990 he married Ms N.R. The couple had one daughter, R.Ó, born on 23 March 1994.
7.  On 24 March 2006 the couple divorced and agreed on custody of the child and other parental rights. Their agreement, which was approved by the Szolnok District Court, placed the daughter with her mother and granted the applicant contact every other weekend, during the school holidays, Easter Sunday, Whit Monday, the first holiday following Christmas Eve and three weeks during the summer holidays. The applicant was also to pay child allowance, amounting to 20% of his salary, but at least 20,000 Hungarian forints (HUF  approximately 66 euros (EUR)) per month.
8.  Ms N.R. moved out of the former family home and took up residence in Budapest.
9.  The applicant could exercise contact on 25 and 26 June and 24 July 2006. However, his daughter was reluctant to stay with him during the summer holidays and preferred to spend her holidays with her grandparents.
10.  The applicant’s further attempts to exercise contact failed, seemingly because in the mother’s view it was up to the child to decide whether she wanted to see her father. The applicant applied to the Szolnok County Guardianship Authority to have the contact agreement enforced. In a decision of 11 September 2006 it ordered Ms N.R. to comply with the agreement, warning her that failure to do so could result in her being fined and ordered to reimburse the applicant’s travel costs. Given the strained relationship between the parents, a notary initiated child protection proceedings ( védelembe vétel ) on 27 December 2006. Subsequently, on a number of occasions Ms N.R. was fined for not complying with the agreement. It appears from the case file that the applicant could exercise contact between 10 July 2007 and 10 November 2008.
11.  In 2007 Ms N.R. brought an action seeking to change the applicant’s contact rights and an increase in the amount of child allowance. In a counterclaim the applicant requested that the child be placed in his custody.
12.  The applicant also filed a criminal complaint against Ms N.R. alleging child endangerment. The parties’ attempt to stabilise the relationship between the applicant and his daughter during the suspension of the custody proceedings were unsuccessful and the Szolnok District Court ordered that any meetings between them take place at a child protection centre.
13.  In a judgment of 10 June 2008 the Szolnok District Court reduced the applicant’s contact with his daughter to every first and third Saturday of the month from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. It held that the previously agreed form of contact was unlikely to be implemented and would only lead to further proceedings before the guardianship authority, which would be to the detriment of the child. The court based its judgment on an expert opinion finding that the child should have had an adaptation period to re-establish her relationship with her father. The court dismissed the applicant’s claim concerning custody, stating that the child’s wishes had to be taken into account, given that she was now fourteen years of age.
14.  On 19 November 2008 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court upheld the first-instance judgment in essence but amended the applicant’s contact rights to every other Saturday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. until 31 May 2009, and all weekend-long visits every other weekend as of 1 June 2009.
15.  In 2009 the applicant failed to turn up at numerous scheduled meetings for months, for which he was fined HUF 10,000 (approximately EUR 35).
16.  In 2010 the applicant’s contact rights and the amount of child allowance were subject to further litigation. On 29 January 2010 the Szolnok District Court dismissed an action brought by him seeking to decrease the amount of child allowance, and a review of the way contact should be exercised. The court established that since the court decision of 19 November 2008, no contact had taken place between the applicant and his daughter and, despite a request by the applicant, the guardianship authority had taken no steps to implement the judgment on the grounds that he had made no efforts to resolve the conflict with his daughter. In particular, he had paid no heed to her request to travel by public transport instead of in his car.
The court also found that in the absence of any significant change in circumstances, there was no reason to amend the arrangements for contact.
17.  In a final judgment of 15 April 2010 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court reviewed the applicant’s parental rights, granting him contact every other weekend on the condition that the daughter, who was by now already 16 years old, be allowed to visit him by herself. The court dismissed the applicant’s request for a decrease in the child allowance. The applicant lodged a petition for review with the Supreme Court. It was dismissed on 8 February 2011.
18.  It appears from the case file that meetings between the applicant and his daughter only took place sporadically in 2010 and did not happen at all in 2011, despite the applicant lodging numerous enforcement requests with the guardianship authority.
19.  In 2011 the applicant requested that the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok Guardianship Authority and all subordinate guardianship authorities be excluded from any further proceedings for bias. On 12 December 2011 the Budapest Regional Guardianship Authority appointed the Budapest XV District Guardianship Authority to deal with any further proceedings concerning the enforcement of the applicant’s contact rights, noting that at that point there were eight enforcement requests pending, the oldest dating back to January 2010.
20.  The applicant lodged a number of requests seeking to end his obligation to pay child allowance, which were finally accepted by the Budapest IV and XV District Court on 10 October 2012 and on appeal by the Budapest High Court on 3 September 2013. Nonetheless, an additional request by him for the reimbursement of the child allowance he had already paid was dismissed at both levels of jurisdiction.
II.  RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW
21.  The relevant rules concerning the enforcement of contact orders are contained in Government Decree no. 149/1997 (IX. 10.) on Guardianship Authorities and Child Protection and Guardianship Proceedings, which provides:
Section 33
“(2) A child’s development is endangered where the person entitled or obliged to maintain child contact repeatedly neglects, deliberately, to comply or to properly comply with the [contact arrangements], and thereby fails to ensure uninterrupted contact.
...
(4) Where, in examining compliance with subsections (1)-(2), the guardianship authority establishes [culpability on the parent’s side], it shall, by a decision, order the enforcement of the child contact within thirty days from the receipt of the enforcement request. In the enforcement order it shall:
a) invite the non-complying party to meet, according to the time and manner specified in the contact order, his or her obligations in respect of the contact due after the receipt of the order and to refrain from turning the child against the other parent,
b) warn the non-complying party of the legal consequences of own-fault non-compliance with the obligations under subsection (a),
c) oblige the non-complying party to bear any justified costs incurred by the frustration of contact.
(5) Where the person entitled or obliged to maintain contact fails to meet the obligations specified in the enforcement order under subsection (4), the guardianship authority may ...
a) initiate the involvement of the child contact centre of the child welfare service or take the child into protection in the event that the maintenance of contact causes arguments, or is continuously frustrated by difficulties, or the parents have problems in communicating,
b) initiate a child protection mediation procedure ....
...
(7) If it is established that during the child’s upbringing the parent/person obliged to allow [contact] to the non-custodial parent/person continuously turns him/her against the person entitled to contact and, despite the enforcement measures specified in subsections (4)-(5), fails to comply with the contact order, the guardianship authority:
a) may bring an action seeking a change to the place of care if it is in the best interests of the child,
b) shall file a criminal complaint ...”

On 14 March 2016 this complaint was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.

On 24 March 2006 the couple divorced and agreed on custody of the child and other parental rights. Their agreement, which was approved by the Szolnok District Court, placed the daughter with her mother and granted the applicant contact every other weekend, during the school holidays, Easter Sunday, Whit Monday, the first holiday following Christmas Eve and three weeks during the summer holidays. The applicant’s further attempts to exercise contact failed, seemingly because in the mother’s view it was up to the child to decide whether she wanted to see her father. The applicant applied to the Szolnok County Guardianship Authority to have the contact agreement enforced.

In 2009 the applicant failed to turn up at numerous scheduled meetings for months, for which he was fined HUF 10,000 (approximately EUR 35).

In 2010 the applicant’s contact rights and the amount of child allowance were subject to further litigation. The court established that since the court decision of 19 November 2008, no contact had taken place between the applicant and his daughter and, despite a request by the applicant, the guardianship authority had taken no steps to implement the judgment on the grounds that he had made no efforts to resolve the conflict with his daughter. events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 38647/09) against Hungary lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Hungarian national, Mr Gábor Ónodi (“the applicant”), on 16 July 2009.
The applicant was represented by Ms M. Regász, a lawyer practising in Budapest. The Hungarian Government (“the Government”) were represented by Mr Z. Tallódi, Agent, Ministry of Justice.
The applicant alleged, in particular, that the Hungarian authorities had failed to take effective steps to enforce his right to contact with his daughter, in breach of Article 8 of the Convention.
On 14 March 2016 this complaint was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
On 6 October 2010 he married Ms N.R. The couple had one daughter, R.Ó, born on 23 March 1994.
On 24 March 2006 the couple divorced and agreed on custody of the child and other parental rights.
On 11 September 2006 it ordered Ms N.R. to comply with the agreement, warning her that failure to do so could result in her being fined and ordered to reimburse the applicant’s travel costs.
Subsequently, on a number of occasions Ms N.R. was fined for not complying with the agreement.
In 2007 Ms N.R. brought an action seeking to change the applicant’s contact rights and an increase in the amount of child allowance.
In a judgment of 10 June 2008 the Szolnok District Court reduced the applicant’s contact with his daughter to every first and third Saturday of the month from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

In a judgment of 19 November 2008 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court upheld the first-instance judgment in essence but amended the applicant’s contact rights to every other Saturday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. until 31 May 2009, and all weekend-long visits every other weekend as of 1 June 2009.
In 2010 the applicant’s contact rights and the amount of child allowance were subject to further litigation.
events.event_who: the applicant’s contact rights and the amount of child allowance

events.source_text: On 29 January 2010 the Szolnok District Court dismissed an action brought by him seeking to decrease the amount of child allowance, and a review of the way contact should be exercised.

In a final judgment of 15 April 2010 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court reviewed the applicant’s parental rights, granting him contact every other weekend on the condition that the daughter, who was by now already 16 years old, be allowed to visit him by herself.
The applicant lodged a petition for review with the Supreme Court. It was dismissed on 8 February 2011.

On 12 December 2011 the Budapest Regional Guardianship Authority appointed the Budapest XV District Guardianship Authority to deal with any further proceedings concerning the enforcement of the applicant’s contact rights, noting that at that point there were eight enforcement requests pending, the oldest dating back to January 2010.

The applicant lodged a number of requests seeking to end his obligation to pay child allowance, which were finally accepted by the Budapest IV and XV District Court on 10 October 2012 and on appeal by the Budapest High Court on 3 September 2013.
events.event_who: the Budapest IV and XV District Court

events.source_text: Declares the application admissible;
Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;

The applicant alleged, in particular, that the Hungarian authorities had failed to take effective steps to enforce his right to contact with his daughter, in breach of Article 8 of the Convention.
On 14 March 2016 this complaint was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 30 May 2017, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.

events.source_text: The applicant also filed a criminal complaint against Ms N.R. alleging child endangerment.
events.event: The applicant filed a criminal complaint

events.source_text: The parties’ attempt to stabilise the relationship between the applicant and his daughter during the suspension of the custody proceedings were unsuccessful and the Szolnok District Court ordered that any meetings between them take place at a child protection centre.
events.event: Meetings between the applicant and his daughter were ordered to take place at a child protection center

events.source_text: In a judgment of 10 June 2008 the Szolnok District Court reduced the applicant’s contact with his daughter to every first and third Saturday of the month from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.
events.event: The court reduced the applicant's contact rights

events.source_text: It held that the previously agreed form of contact was unlikely to be implemented and would only lead to further proceedings before the guardianship authority, which would be to the detriment of the child.
The court based its judgment on an expert opinion finding that the child should have had an adaptation period to re-establish her relationship with her father.
events.event: The court based its decision on an expert opinion

events.source_text: The court dismissed the applicant’s claim concerning custody, stating that the child’s wishes had to be taken into account, given that she was now fourteen years of age.
events.event: The court dismissed the applicant's claim for custody

events.source_text: On 19 November 2008 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court upheld the first-instance judgment in essence but amended the applicant’s contact rights to every other Saturday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. until 31 May 2009, and all weekend-long visits every other weekend as of 1 June 2009.
events.event: The court amended the applicant's contact rights

events.source_text: In 2009 the applicant failed to turn up at numerous scheduled meetings for months, for which he was fined HUF 10,000 (approximately EUR 35).
events.event: The applicant missed scheduled meetings and was fined

events.source_text: In 2010 the applicant’s contact rights and the amount of child allowance were subject to further litigation.
events.event: The applicant's contact rights and child allowance were subject to further litigation

events.source_text: On 29 January 2010 the Szolnok District Court dismissed an action brought by him seeking to decrease the amount of child allowance, and a review of the way contact should be exercised.
events.event: The court dismissed the applicant's request to decrease child allowance

events.source_text: The court established that since the court decision of 19 November 2008, no contact had taken place between the applicant and his daughter and, despite a request by the applicant, the guardianship authority had taken no steps to implement the judgment on the grounds that he had made no efforts to resolve the conflict with his daughter.
events.event: The court established the lack of contact between the applicant and his daughter

events.source_text: In particular, he had paid no heed to her request to travel by public transport instead of in his car.
events.event: The applicant ignored the daughter's request for travel arrangements

events.source_text: In the absence of any significant change in circumstances, there was no reason to amend the arrangements for contact.
events.event: The court found no reason to amend the contact arrangements

events.source_text: In a final judgment of 15 April 2010 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court reviewed the applicant’s parental rights, granting him contact every other weekend on the condition that the daughter, who was by now already 16 years old, be allowed to visit him by herself.
events.event: The court reviewed the applicant's parental rights

events.source_text: The court dismissed the applicant’s request for a decrease in the child allowance.
events.event: The court dismissed the applicant's request for a decrease in child allowance

events.source_text: The applicant lodged a petition for review with the Supreme Court. It was dismissed on 8 February 2011.
events.event: The applicant's petition for review was dismissed

events.source_text: It appears from the case file that meetings between the applicant and his daughter only took place sporadically in 2010 and did not happen at all in 2011, despite the applicant lodging numerous enforcement requests with the guardianship authority.
events.event: The applicant's attempts to have contact were unsuccessful
events.event_what: took place sporadically or did not happen at all

events.source_text: In 2011 the applicant requested that the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok Guardianship Authority and all subordinate guardianship authorities be excluded from any further proceedings for bias.
events.event: The applicant requested exclusion of the guardianship authority

events.source_text: On 12 December 2011 the Budapest Regional Guardianship Authority appointed the Budapest XV District Guardianship Authority to deal with any further proceedings concerning the enforcement of the applicant’s contact rights, noting that at that point there were eight enforcement requests pending, the oldest dating back to January 2010.
events.event: The guardianship authority was appointed to handle further proceedings

events.source_text: The applicant lodged a number of requests seeking to end his obligation to pay child allowance, which were finally accepted by the Budapest IV and XV District Court on 10 October 2012 and on appeal by the Budapest High Court on 3 September 2013.
events.event: The applicant's request to end child allowance was granted
events.event_who: Budapest IV and XV District Court, Budapest High Court

events.source_text: Nonetheless, an additional request by him for the reimbursement of the child allowance he had already paid was dismissed at both levels of jurisdiction.
events.event: The applicant's request for reimbursement of child allowance was dismissed

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
events.event: The court made a unanimous decision

events.source_text: Declares the application admissible;
events.event: The court declared the application admissible

events.source_text: Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event: The court found a violation of Article 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: Holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:
events.event: The court ordered the respondent state to pay the applicant

events.source_text: (i) EUR 6,000 (six thousand euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage;
events.event: The court ordered the respondent state to pay non-pecuniary damages

events.source_text: (ii) EUR 1,900 (one thousand nine hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable to the applicant, in respect of costs and expenses;
events.event: The court ordered the respondent state to pay costs and expenses

events.source_text: (b) that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
events.event: The court ordered simple interest on the above amounts

events.source_text: 4. Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
events.event: The court dismissed the remainder of the applicant's claim for just satisfaction

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 30 May 2017, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event: The judgment was made and notified

4. On 14 March 2016 this complaint was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
7. On 24 March 2006 the couple divorced and agreed on custody of the child and other parental rights.
7. On 24 March 2006 the couple divorced and agreed on custody of the child and other parental rights.
10. The applicant could exercise contact on 25 and 26 June and 24 July 2006.
11. In 2007 Ms N.R. brought an action seeking to change the applicant’s contact rights and an increase in the amount of child allowance.
11. In 2007 Ms N.R. brought an action seeking to change the applicant’s contact rights and an increase in the amount of child allowance.
13. In a judgment of 10 June 2008 the Szolnok District Court reduced the applicant’s contact with his daughter to every first and third Saturday of the month from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

14. On 19 November 2008 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court upheld the first-instance judgment in essence but amended the applicant’s contact rights to every other Saturday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m.
15. In 2009 the applicant failed to turn up at numerous scheduled meetings for months, for which he was fined HUF 10,000 (approximately EUR 35).

events.source_text: 16. In 2010 the applicant’s contact rights and the amount of child allowance were subject to further litigation.

17. In a final judgment of 15 April 2010 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court reviewed the applicant’s parental rights, granting him contact every other weekend on the condition that the daughter, who was by now already 16 years old, be allowed to visit him by herself.
events.event_what: reviewed parental rights and granted contact

events.source_text: 19. In 2011 the applicant requested that the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok Guardianship Authority and all subordinate guardianship authorities be excluded from any further proceedings for bias.
19. In 2011 the applicant requested that the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok Guardianship Authority and all subordinate guardianship authorities be excluded from any further proceedings for bias.
20. The applicant lodged a number of requests seeking to end his obligation to pay child allowance, which were finally accepted by the Budapest IV and XV District Court on 10 October 2012.

21. The relevant rules concerning the enforcement of contact orders are contained in Government Decree no. 149/1997 (IX. 10.) on Guardianship Authorities and Child Protection and Guardianship Proceedings.

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 30 May 2017, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.

The case originated in an application (no. 38647/09) against Hungary lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Hungarian national, Mr Gábor Ónodi (“the applicant”), on 16 July 2009.
events.event_what: lodged an application against Hungary under Article 34 of the Convention

events.source_text: The applicant alleged, in particular, that the Hungarian authorities had failed to take effective steps to enforce his right to contact with his daughter, in breach of Article 8 of the Convention.
events.event_what: alleged that the Hungarian authorities had failed to enforce his right to contact with his daughter, breaching Article 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: On 14 March 2016 this complaint was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event: Application communicated and partially declared inadmissible
events.event_what: communicated the complaint to the Government and declared the remainder of the application inadmissible

events.source_text: In a judgment of 10 June 2008 the Szolnok District Court reduced the applicant’s contact with his daughter to every first and third Saturday of the month from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.
events.event_what: reduced the applicant’s contact with his daughter

events.source_text: In a final judgment of 15 April 2010 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court reviewed the applicant’s parental rights, granting him contact every other weekend on the condition that the daughter be allowed to visit him by herself.
events.event_what: reviewed the applicant’s parental rights and granted him contact every other weekend with conditions

events.source_text: The Court, UNANIMOUSLY, ... Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event_what: held that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Szajol.

events.event_what: got married and had a daughter, R.Ó, born on 23 March 1994

events.source_text: On 24 March 2006 the couple divorced and agreed on custody of the child and other parental rights.
events.event_who: the applicant (Mr Gábor Ónodi) and Ms N.R.
events.event_what: divorced and agreed on custody of their child and other parental rights

events.source_text: Their agreement, which was approved by the Szolnok District Court, placed the daughter with her mother and granted the applicant contact every other weekend, during the school holidays, Easter Sunday, Whit Monday, the first holiday following Christmas Eve and three weeks during the summer holidays. The applicant was also to pay child allowance, amounting to 20% of his salary, but at least 20,000 Hungarian forints (HUF) approximately 66 euros (EUR)) per month.
events.event_who: the applicant (Mr Gábor Ónodi) and Ms N.R.
events.event_what: reached an agreement, approved by the Szolnok District Court, placing their daughter with her mother, granting the applicant contact every other weekend, during school holidays, and three weeks in the summer, and requiring the applicant to pay child allowance amounting to 20% of his salary but at least HUF 20,000 per month

events.source_text: Ms N.R. moved out of the former family home and took up residence in Budapest.

The applicant’s further attempts to exercise contact failed, seemingly because in the mother’s view it was up to the child to decide whether she wanted to see her father.

events.source_text: In a decision of 11 September 2006 it ordered Ms N.R. to comply with the agreement, warning her that failure to do so could result in her being fined and ordered to reimburse the applicant’s travel costs.
events.event_what: ordered Ms N.R. to comply with the contact agreement, warning her that failure to do so could result in her being fined and ordered to reimburse the applicant’s travel costs

events.source_text: Given the strained relationship between the parents, a notary initiated child protection proceedings ( védelembe vétel ) on 27 December 2006.
events.event_what: initiated child protection proceedings given the strained relationship between the parents

events.source_text: In 2007 Ms N.R. brought an action seeking to change the applicant’s contact rights and an increase in the amount of child allowance.
events.event_what: brought an action seeking to change the applicant’s contact rights and increase the amount of child allowance

events.source_text: In a counterclaim the applicant requested that the child be placed in his custody.
events.event_what: filed a counterclaim requesting that the child be placed in his custody

events.source_text: The applicant also filed a criminal complaint against Ms N.R. alleging child endangerment.
events.event_what: filed a criminal complaint against Ms N.R. alleging child endangerment

events.source_text: The parties’ attempt to stabilise the relationship between the applicant and his daughter during the suspension of the custody proceedings were unsuccessful and the Szolnok District Court ordered that any meetings between them take place at a child protection centre.

events.source_text: The court dismissed the applicant’s claim concerning custody, stating that the child’s wishes had to be taken into account, given that she was now fourteen years of age.
events.event_what: dismissed the applicant’s claim concerning custody, stating that the child’s wishes had to be taken into account given that she was now fourteen years of age

events.source_text: On 19 November 2008 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court upheld the first-instance judgment in essence but amended the applicant’s contact rights to every other Saturday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. until 31 May 2009, and all weekend-long visits every other weekend as of 1 June 2009.
events.event_what: upheld the first-instance judgment in essence but amended the applicant’s contact rights to every other Saturday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. until 31 May 2009, and all weekend-long visits every other weekend as of 1 June 2009

events.source_text: In 2010 the applicant’s contact rights and the amount of child allowance were subject to further litigation. On 29 January 2010 the Szolnok District Court dismissed an action brought by him seeking to decrease the amount of child allowance, and a review of the way contact should be exercised.
events.event_what: dismissed an action brought by the applicant seeking to decrease the amount of child allowance and review the way contact should be exercised

The court dismissed the applicant’s request for a decrease in the child allowance.
events.event_what: reviewed the applicant’s parental rights, granting him contact every other weekend on the condition that the daughter be allowed to visit him by herself and dismissed his request for a decrease in the child allowance

events.source_text: The applicant lodged a petition for review with the Supreme Court. It was dismissed on 8 February 2011.

events.source_text: 1. The case originated in an application (no. 38647/09) against Hungary lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ('the Convention') by a Hungarian national, Mr Gábor Ónodi ('the applicant'), on 16 July 2009.
2. The applicant was represented by Ms M. Regász, a lawyer practising in Budapest. The Hungarian Government ('the Government') were represented by Mr Z. Tallódi, Agent, Ministry of Justice.
3. The applicant alleged, in particular, that the Hungarian authorities had failed to take effective steps to enforce his right to contact with his daughter, in breach of Article 8 of the Convention.
4. On 14 March 2016 this complaint was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 Ó 3 of the Rules of Court.
5. The applicant was born in 1965 and lives in Szajol.
6. On 6 October 1990 he married Ms N.R. The couple had one daughter, R.Ó, born on 23 March 1994.
7. On 24 March 2006 the couple divorced and agreed on custody of the child and other parental rights.
8. Ms N.R. moved out of the former family home and took up residence in Budapest.
9. The applicant could exercise contact on 25 and 26 June and 24 July 2006.
10. The applicantâs further attempts to exercise contact failed, seemingly because in the motherâs view it was up to the child to decide whether she wanted to see her father.
11. In 2007 Ms N.R. brought an action seeking to change the applicantâs contact rights and an increase in the amount of child allowance.
events.event_what: action for change in contact rights, increase in child allowance

events.source_text: 12. The applicant also filed a criminal complaint against Ms N.R. alleging child endangerment.
13. In a judgment of 10 June 2008 the Szolnok District Court reduced the applicantâs contact with his daughter to every first and third Saturday of the month from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

14. On 19 November 2008 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court upheld the first-instance judgment in essence but amended the applicantâs contact rights to every other Saturday between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. until 31 May 2009, and all weekend-long visits every other weekend as of 1 June 2009.
15. In 2009 the applicant failed to turn up at numerous scheduled meetings for months, for which he was fined HUF 10,000 (approximately EUR 35).
16. In 2010 the applicantâs contact rights and the amount of child allowance were subject to further litigation.
events.event_what: further litigation on contact rights, child allowance

events.source_text: 17. In a final judgment of 15 April 2010 the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok County Regional Court reviewed the applicantâs parental rights, granting him contact every other weekend on the condition that the daughter, who was by now already 16 years old, be allowed to visit him by herself.
events.event_what: final judgment, reviewed parental rights, granted contact

events.source_text: 18. It appears from the case file that meetings between the applicant and his daughter only took place sporadically in 2010 and did not happen at all in 2011, despite the applicant lodging numerous enforcement requests with the guardianship authority.
19. In 2011 the applicant requested that the Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok Guardianship Authority and all subordinate guardianship authorities be excluded from any further proceedings for bias.

20. The applicant lodged a number of requests seeking to end his obligation to pay child allowance, which were finally accepted by the Budapest IV and XV District Court on 10 October 2012 and on appeal by the Budapest High Court on 3 September 2013.
events.event_what: requests to end child allowance obligation

events.source_text: II. RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW

21. The relevant rules concerning the enforcement of contact orders are contained in Government Decree no. 149/1997 (IX. 10.) on Guardianship Authorities and Child Protection and Guardianship Proceedings, which provides:
FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
1. Declares the application admissible;
2. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
3. Holds

(a) that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 Ó 2 of the Convention, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:

(b) that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
4. Dismisses the remainder of the applicantâs claim for just satisfaction.
Done in English, and notified in writing on 30 May 2017, pursuant to Rule 77 Ó 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
